headline: Defence Force Gets $2.7B Upgrade as Contentious Bills on Infrastructure and Protest Rights Advance
summary: Parliament was dominated by major government announcements and legislative milestones, including a multi-billion dollar investment in new Defence Force aircraft and the final passage of a controversial bill to speed up infrastructure projects. The day also saw heated debates over the government's changes to pay equity, a weakening of clean car standards, and the introduction of a new bill to criminalise disruptive protests at private homes.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Announces $2.7B Deal for New Defence Helicopters and Planes
topicSummaries.content: The government unveiled its first major investment under the Defence Capability Plan, announcing a $2.7 billion procurement of new aircraft. The deal includes five MH-60R Seahawk helicopters to replace the navy's aging Seasprite fleet and two Airbus A321XLR aircraft to succeed the 32-year-old Boeing 757s. Defence Minister Judith Collins framed the purchase as a "once-in-a-generation" investment in national security, enhancing combat capability and ensuring interoperability with allies like Australia and the United States. The new aircraft are intended to improve surveillance, transport, and long-range operational capacity, including for missions to Antarctica.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon JUDITH COLLINS (Minister of Defence)
keyExchanges.quote: Today, I announced the first major investment decisions to be made as part of the Government's Defence Capability Plan (DCP). I was delighted to announce that the MH-60R Seahawk is the preferred option to replace the existing maritime helicopters, and that the Airbus A321XLR aircraft will replace the ageing 757 fleet. These represent once-in-a-generation investments in our national security to ensure our economic prosperity.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon JUDITH COLLINS (Minister of Defence)
keyExchanges.quote: These extra long-range aircraft will be capable of returning safely from Antarctica if they are unable to land due to conditions on the ice. This is not a capability that we've ever had before... They will be able to also fly as far as Singapore without needing to stop and refuel. It's a decision that reflects the need for New Zealand to have a reliable aircraft for our personnel, to deliver military equipment and humanitarian aid, support the evacuation of civilians, and transport Government trade and diplomat delegations quickly over long distances, often at short notice.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Grilled Over Impact of Pay Equity Changes on Women
topicSummaries.content: During a fiery Question Time, Minister for Workplace Relations and Safety Brooke van Velden faced intense scrutiny from Labour's Deputy Leader Carmel Sepuloni over the government's changes to the pay equity system. Sepuloni argued that the changes would force 180,000 workers, mostly women, to bear the cost of the government's budget decisions and would particularly disadvantage Pasifika women and wāhine Māori. Van Velden defended the policy, stating the pay equity system remains intact and that the changes simply ensure it targets genuine cases of sex-based discrimination, denying that any costs were being passed on to workers.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Deputy Leader—Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why are 180,000 workers—mostly women—being forced to carry the cost of this Government's poor Budget decisions?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon BROOKE VAN VELDEN (Minister for Workplace Relations and Safety)
keyExchanges.quote: That's just not true. They're not being asked to carry any cost. We are simply ensuring that the pay equity system does what it says it does, which is to stamp out genuine cases of sex-based discrimination.

topicSummaries.topic: Public Works Bill to Speed Up Major Projects Passes Final Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Public Works (Critical Infrastructure) Amendment Bill passed its third and final reading, backed by National, ACT, NZ First, and Labour. The legislation is designed to accelerate land acquisition for critical infrastructure projects by streamlining the objections process and offering financial incentives for early agreement, removing most cases from the Environment Court. While the government and Labour supported the bill as a necessary step to address the country's infrastructure deficit, Te Pāti Māori and the Green Party voted against it. Opponents raised serious concerns about the historical use of the Public Works Act to confiscate Māori land and argued the bill strips property rights from everyday New Zealanders.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS PENK (Minister for Land Information)
keyExchanges.quote: Passing this bill will speed up the delivery of critical infrastructure projects and make strides towards addressing New Zealand's infrastructure deficit. Faster infrastructure delivery through streamlined processes and efficient decision-making can ensure that Kiwis benefit from these investments sooner and at a lower financial burden.

keyExchanges.speaker: MARIAMENO KAPA-KINGI (Te Pāti Māori—Te Tai Tokerau)
keyExchanges.quote: The thing at the moment is that "public works" is a dirty word; it has been for some time. The audacity to bring this up and use the same public works—those words—is a foolish and dumb thing, and you're not going to get the response from Māori that you think you deserve.

topicSummaries.topic: New Bill Proposes Offence for Disruptive Protests at Private Homes
topicSummaries.content: The government introduced the Summary Offences (Demonstrations Near Residential Premises) Amendment Bill for its first reading, proposing a new offence for engaging in targeted, disruptive demonstrations outside a person's home. The bill would make such actions punishable by up to three months in jail or a $2,000 fine. The government argued the law is a reasonable limitation needed to protect the privacy and safety of individuals and their families from intimidation. However, Labour, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori strongly opposed the bill, framing it as an attack on the fundamental democratic right to protest and arguing that existing laws for trespass and disorderly behaviour are sufficient.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon JAMES MEAGER (on behalf of the Minister of Justice)
keyExchanges.quote: The new offence will not stop people from demonstrating or from expressing their views. What this new offence will do is provide reasonable boundaries about how people can demonstrate near private residences in order to better protect peoples' rights to privacy and the quiet enjoyment of their own homes.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr DUNCAN WEBB (Labour—Christchurch Central)
keyExchanges.quote: This is targeted to suppress political action, and that's not something that we can support in the Labour Party, and certainly not in this form... Protest is disruptive; that's what a protest is.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Loosens Clean Car Rules in First Reading of New Bill
topicSummaries.content: The Land Transport (Clean Vehicle Standard) Amendment Bill (No 2) passed its first reading, introducing changes the government says will provide more flexibility for vehicle importers. The bill extends the lifespan of carbon credits and allows them to be traded between new and used importers, aiming to prevent higher car prices due to importers failing to meet emission targets. Opposition parties heavily criticised the move, with Labour calling it a "shocker" that weakens climate commitments to benefit industry. The Greens and Te Pāti Māori argued it would make New Zealand a dumping ground for less efficient vehicles and harm the transition to an electric fleet.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister of Transport)
keyExchanges.quote: To prevent this outcome, the bill gives importers more flexibility in how and when they comply with the targets; flexibility is critical because importers can't control all the factors affecting whether they can supply the low-emissions vehicles needed to comply with the targets, nor can they control whether consumers will buy them.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr DEBORAH RUSSELL (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is a bit of a shocker, really. It's an extraordinary thing that that side of the House is doing. It stacks up with all their other climate-denying work, but this one is a bit of a corker.

conclusion: The government successfully advanced its agenda on defence and infrastructure, while simultaneously opening new fronts of debate over fundamental rights to protest and the direction of the country's climate policy.
